nodes.bodyText: While you are changing code here anyway: Can you convert the runnable to a private void poll()?

I agree that the null-check like it was before does nothing,  but I wonder if removing is the correct way. Are you sure that every access to service is null-safe? Otherwise it would be probably better to throw an IllegalArgumentException.
The correct way would obviously be to add proper null-annotations, but that is out-of-scope of this PR.

The Sonos handler factory bundle will not start without this bundle. It is set as a reference:
https://github.com/openhab/openhab-addons/blob/2.5.x/bundles/org.openhab.binding.sonos/src/main/java/org/openhab/binding/sonos/internal/SonosHandlerFactory.java#L74
So it cannot be null at this place, in the constructor of the Sonos thing handler.
That is exactly the same thing as for thingRegistry or stateDescriptionProvider.

This method is not called only by the polling job.
I see what you mean, we should avoid to run it just after the thing handler was disposed.
Why did you change the way this was implemented? It looks like it was intended to update properties if they haven't changed. Now you are updating the properties every time.
I changed it because this was useless, the method updateProperties from the core framework is already checking if each property is updated before changing it.
